physDesc.p: This letter is 3 pages long (seq. 22-24). It is typed on something like notebook paper and words are printed on the page in a slanted manner at times,.The words "John Gould " are written in pencil across the top of the first page. Unsigned.

editorialDecl.p: This letter contains references to the following:

body.p: I am enclosing two reviews which Richard sent me. Hueffer’s, as you see, is a very nasty attack upon us three, no one of us being willing to kowtow to him. It seems that he tried to persuade Richard to leave us in the lurch last winter and have nothing more to do with us. I think Richard has behaved awfully well, as he absolutely refused to listen. Of course, the violent praise of Flint is by way of putting us still farther in the background. I do not mind the article in the least, and I hope you won’t; and I think the dignified thing for us to do is to pretend we have not seen it or, if we have, that it is not worthy of attention. That is what Richard is going to do, and that is what I am going to do. Hueffer is a beastly German cad. Richard says that he and Ezra are thick again. He is just sore about Ferris Greenslet not being willing to print his "Heaven." We are quitting him for good, and I am not sorry.

The other article is by Edward Storer in the "British Review," and, as Richard says, it means to be nice. But Richard says he greatly prefers the Greek things, so that he likes Richard and Hilda best. I am sorry he understands you so little, but the review just shows how different the American and the English types of mind are. The Americans have some comprehension of the imaginative, and the English not a rag.

I was not overcome with joy at Padraic Colum’s article on us. But then, what can you expect? He has his way to make, and he obviously is not one of us; so he thinks the best rôle to pursue is that of the superior critic.

I do not think it is worth while your writing to "The Transcript" about the preface. We all agree with your preface absolutely and, though it did not happen to be the preface to "Some Imagist Poets," it might have been; and in slamming it, they are slamming their point of view just as much as yours.

A ridiculous paper here called "Zion’s Herald" put in a piece to the effect that I was the editor of the New Poetry Series. I wrote to them at once, because I am certainly not going to be made responsible for Greenslet’s taste.
Mrs. Russell is much. better, I am thankful to say, and she leaves day after to-morrow for the West, and I go up to Dublin on Friday. So send your next letter there.
I trust the baby is better, and that your sister’s trip to Chicago will do her good.
